g.text: A commonly used method for limiting occurrences of near-zero spatial gradients in calculation of climate
velocities is adding a small random noise to their values
. In this random noise method, the user directly deter-
mines the range of generated “uncertainties”, usually small in magnitude relative to the signal for which they are
generated. Here we use a bootstrap method
that, on the other hand, requires user input about the number of
generated time series from which the uncertainty range is calculated and not the range itself. The assumption
about optimal calculation can be tested by adding more generated series to the analysis, hence making boot-
strap more mathematically rigorous (less arbitrary) than the random noise generation. In any case, the choice of
method for limiting near-zero spatial gradients can significantly affect only the extreme values of climate veloci-
ties, usually related to lowland areas, and therefore we recommend the use of a bootstrap method in calculation
Data based studies like the one we present here can help to further explore the causal links and attribution
of species shifts across multiple taxa to local and regional climate variability. Species from multiple taxonomic
groups have different climatic requirements and heterogeneous responses to climate change (i.e. either on the
individualistic or population level) that are not fully understood
. Some studies have used biotic velocity (met-
rics developed based on climatic niche models)
, and have analysed plant species vulnerability (on a pop-
ulation level) to local climate change velocity and their migration abilities (i.e. dispersal abilities)
studies use species distribution data from range maps which are scale dependent, and this could overestimate the
presence of a particular species. In other words, they do not use species occurrence data
understand to what extent species have followed previous climate change velocity at the local and regional scales,
we need studies based on occurrence data. Such studies can serve as a guide to estimating the rate of future eco-
logical migrations driven by climate velocity.
With the continued rapid climate change that is anticipated for coming decades, fine scales studies on a seasonal
climate change and velocity analysis over the past century and in particular over the past 60–70 years are neces-
sary to understand biological responses of different taxonomic groups and to identify the most vulnerable species,
. Such regional/local scale climate change baseline studies do not only open the door
for more necessary collaboration between climate change scientists and ecologists, but they also allow better clari-
fications between recent biodiversity changes and their impact on ecosystem services
more accurate future projections and to more effective policy and biodiversity management planning
Therefore, we argue for more combined research on detecting the magnitude/velocity of seasonal climate varia-
bility (as many species do not respond to the mean annual temperature or precipitation change)
shifts in the species’ geographical distribution at local and regional spatial scales.
1. Bellard, C., Bertelsmeier, C., Leadley, P., Thuiller, W. & Courchamp, F. Impacts of climate change on the future of biodiversity.
2. Parmesan, C. Ecological and Evolutionary Responses to Recent Climate Change.
Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and
. Linking Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services: Current Uncertainties and the Necessary Next Steps.
. Assessing species vulnerability to climate change.
5. Primack, R. B. & Gallinat, A. S. Insights into grass phenology from herbarium specimens.
. Climate change, climatic variation and extreme biological responses.
Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society
7. IPCC. Climate Change 2014, Synthesis Report, Summary for Policymakers. Contribution of Working Groups I, II and III to the Fifth
Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. 1–32 (Geneva, Switzerland 2014).
8. Lewis, S. L. & Maslin, M. A. Defining the Anthropocene.
9. Ummenhofer, C. C. & Meehl, G. A. Extreme weather and climate events with ecological relevance: a review.
Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences
10. Parmesan, C. & Yohe, G. A globally coherent fingerprint of climate change impacts across natural systems.
. Global exchange and accumulation of non-native plants.
12. Baker, D. J., Hartley, A. J., Pearce-Higgins, J. W., Jones, R. G. & Willis, S. G. Neglected issues in using weather and climate information
13. Costa, A. & Soares, A. Homogenization of Climate Data: Review and New Perspectives Using Geostatistics.
. Global assessment of trends in wetting and drying over land.
15. Parmesan, C., Duarte, C., Poloczanska, E., Richardson, A. J. & Singer, M. C. Overstretching attribution.
16. Parmesan, C. & Hanley, M. E. Plants and climate change: complexities and surprises.
. Biodiversity loss and its impact on humanity.
. Do invasive alien plants benefit more from global environmental change than native plants?
20. Haeuser, E., Dawson, W. & van Kleunen, M. The effects of climate warming and disturbance on the colonization potential of
. Geographical limits to species-range shifts are suggested by climate velocity.
